document.text: Green Goods The Charge. . Bristol,-J. N. Harwood, charged ! with operating a green goods scheme through the United States mails under the alias W. A. Wales, was arrested here by Deputy Marshal Jacob Hawkins. Harwood, who is an East Tennesseean and about 40  vears old, is accused of mailing  green goods letters and circulars from Bristol and Johnson City. Tfae Case was brought to the atten tion1 of - j R. W. Hodgin, a postoffice inspector of Greensboro, N. C. Hod- gin found one of the Harwood let ters at Elk Park, N. C. He answered it. inclosing in a registered letter the amount ofn money requested for the original puroiiase. When Harwood called for and received the register ed -letter, his arrest followed. Harwood in Is letters claimed to represent a Rtetroit Mich. green goods firm, and proposed to sell the goods upon the basis of 25 per cent, of genuine currency in pay ments.

document.text: Liberty Baptist Church O. D. Moore, Pastor Vacation Bible School begins at Liberty Monday, June 8 and continues through Friday, June 12, 845  1145 a.m. each day, ages 3 through 16. Preparation Day is Saturday, June 6, 2 p.m. The Pastor, O. D. Moore is serv ing as Principal, and the follow ing will serve as Department Superintendents Nursery care Mrs. Gilbert Mays Nursery, Mrs. O. D. Moore Beginner Mrs. O .B. Garris Prim ary Mrs Jacob Lewis Junior, Mrs. Ro bert Hubbard and. Mrs. A. R. Harwood, Jr. Intermediate, Mrs W. E. Jamerson

document.text: i yjn II- Robinson, of Appomattox I a brother, J. D. Howell, Jr of Norfolk and a sister, Mrs. W. ! a . Jenkins, of Norfolk. I Funeral services were conduct- I ed at 11 a.m. Monday, Sept. 24, I from the Robinson Funeral Home I in Appomattox by the Rev. O. D.  Moore and Rev. William Snead. Burial was in Liberty Cemetery. Pallbearers were J. Lloyd Hud son, Kenneth Coleman, Ed Caw- thorne, Watkins Abbitt, C. T. Moses, Sr., A. R. Harwood J. C. Caldwell and Jacob Lewis.

document.text: The Rachel C. OBrien pro perty sold Saturday to A. R. Harwood at 5,390. The pestiferious mosquitor and the nerve wrecking R. R. whistle must be silenced in this town of heretofore happy homes. Messrs. Isaac and Jacob Lewis motored on a business trip Friday to Buckingham C. H., Dillwyn, Prospect and Pamplin. POULTRY WANTED Hens not leghorns, anconas, tec., 22 to 24c. We will buy any quantity any time. VALLEY POULTRY CO., 613 Fifth St., Lynchburg, Va. Commissioners Clement, Lewis and Campbell sold Pamplin Pipe and Manufactur ing Co., property Saturday at auction for 8000 to J. F. Con- nally. Two nuisancesmosquitors and R. R. whistlestown coun cil c.an eliminate both promptly and receive the applaud of a grateful public. Why not do it now? Archer Richardson, who lives on Joel Colemans farm near Hurtsville, was arrested and brought here and placed in jail on complaint of his wife for non-support. He is charged with making wiskey and other charges are against him. He came here from J3.  W., Va., it is said. At a hear ing Monday he was sent on to grand jury on liquor charge.
